active_immunity.formula: Active immunity develops when the individual's own immune system responds to antigens and forms memory
active_immunity.correct: Active immunity is long-lasting because the person produces their own memory B and T cells

wrong.fix: Active immunity takes days to weeks to develop; passive immunity is immediate
wrong.action: Active = delayed but lasting; Passive = immediate but temporary

wrong.fix: Active immunity involves making your own antibodies; receiving antibodies is passive
wrong.action: Active = make your own; Passive = receive from another source

wrong.error: Missing the key feature of active immunity
wrong.fix: Memory formation is the defining feature of active immunity
wrong.action: Active immunity = memory cells formed = long-lasting protection

persistent.action: Active immunity: own immune response, memory formed, long-lasting, slower onset

passive_immunity.formula: Passive immunity is acquired by receiving pre-formed antibodies from another source
passive_immunity.correct: Passive immunity provides immediate but temporary protection because no memory cells are formed

wrong.fix: Passive immunity is temporary (weeks to months) because antibodies degrade and no memory forms
wrong.action: Passive = temporary (antibodies degrade); Active = long-lasting (memory)

wrong.answer: Passive immunity requires exposure to pathogens
wrong.fix: Passive immunity receives ready-made antibodies; no pathogen exposure needed
wrong.action: Passive = receive antibodies; Active = respond to pathogens/vaccines

wrong.error: Not understanding why passive is temporary
wrong.fix: No memory forms in passive immunity because the recipient's immune system isn't activated
wrong.action: Passive = no activation = no memory = temporary

persistent.action: Passive: receive antibodies, immediate, temporary, no memory formed

natural_active.formula: Natural active immunity develops after recovery from natural infection
natural_active.correct: Exposure to the pathogen triggers immune response and memory, providing protection against reinfection

wrong.fix: Natural = through infection; Artificial = through medical intervention (vaccines)
wrong.action: Natural = infection/maternal; Artificial = vaccines/antisera

wrong.answer: Natural active immunity doesn't involve the immune system
wrong.error: Contradicting the definition of active immunity
wrong.fix: Active immunity always involves the individual's immune system responding and forming memory
wrong.action: Active always = own immune response

wrong.answer: Natural active immunity provides immediate protection
wrong.error: Not understanding the time needed for immune response
wrong.fix: Protection develops as the immune response clears the infection (days to weeks)
wrong.action: Protection develops during/after infection, not immediately

persistent.action: Natural active: infection → immune response → recovery → memory → lasting protection

artificial_active.formula: Artificial active immunity is induced by vaccination with antigens or attenuated pathogens
artificial_active.correct: Vaccines stimulate immune responses and memory without causing disease

wrong.fix: Vaccines contain antigens that stimulate your immune system; antisera contain antibodies
wrong.action: Vaccines = antigens → active immunity; Antisera = antibodies → passive immunity

wrong.answer: Vaccines cause the disease they prevent
wrong.fix: Vaccines use killed, attenuated, or partial pathogens that can't cause disease
wrong.action: Vaccines: killed/attenuated/subunit = safe antigens, no disease

wrong.fix: Vaccine immunity is active (forms memory) and is therefore long-lasting
wrong.action: Vaccines → active immunity → memory → long-lasting (may need boosters)

persistent.action: Vaccines: contain antigens, stimulate active immunity, form memory, long-lasting

natural_passive.formula: Natural passive immunity is acquired through transfer of maternal antibodies
natural_passive.correct: Antibodies cross the placenta (IgG) and are present in breast milk (IgA), protecting newborns

wrong.answer: Maternal antibodies are produced by the baby
wrong.fix: Maternal antibodies are made by the mother and transferred to the baby
wrong.action: Passive = received from another source (mother)

wrong.fix: Maternal antibodies degrade over months; babies then rely on their own immunity
wrong.action: Maternal antibodies last ~6 months; baby must develop own immunity

wrong.answer: Only IgG is transferred to babies
wrong.fix: IgG crosses placenta; IgA is in breast milk providing mucosal protection
wrong.action: Placenta = IgG; Breast milk = IgA (different routes, different antibodies)

persistent.action: Natural passive: placental IgG + breast milk IgA → temporary newborn protection

artificial_passive.formula: Artificial passive immunity is provided by injection of pre-formed antibodies (antisera or immunoglobulins)
artificial_passive.correct: Antisera provide immediate protection for exposures like snake bites or rabies

wrong.fix: Antisera provide ready-made antibodies; no immune activation or memory occurs
wrong.action: Antisera = passive = no memory = temporary

wrong.error: Not understanding the advantage of passive immunity
wrong.fix: Antisera work immediately because antibodies are pre-formed and ready to act
wrong.action: Passive = immediate; Active = delayed

wrong.answer: Antisera are the same as vaccines
wrong.fix: Vaccines contain antigens (active); antisera contain antibodies (passive)
wrong.action: Vaccines = antigens → active; Antisera = antibodies → passive

persistent.action: Antisera: contain antibodies, immediate protection, temporary, no memory

vaccine_types.formula: Vaccines can be live attenuated, inactivated, subunit, toxoid, or nucleic acid-based
vaccine_types.correct: Different vaccine types balance immunogenicity with safety for different diseases

wrong.fix: Only live attenuated vaccines contain replicating organisms; others are safer alternatives
wrong.action: Types: live attenuated, killed/inactivated, subunit, toxoid, mRNA, viral vector

wrong.answer: Subunit vaccines cause stronger immunity than live vaccines
wrong.fix: Live attenuated vaccines typically induce stronger immunity but have more risks
wrong.action: Live = stronger immunity, more risk; Subunit = weaker immunity, safer

wrong.fix: mRNA stays in cytoplasm, is translated to protein, then degraded; it never enters nucleus
wrong.action: mRNA → protein (cytoplasm) → degraded; Never enters nucleus or affects DNA

persistent.gap: Confusion about vaccine types and mechanisms
persistent.action: Compare: live (strong, risky), killed (moderate), subunit (safe, weak), mRNA (safe, effective)

herd_immunity.formula: Herd immunity occurs when enough of the population is immune to reduce disease spread
herd_immunity.correct: High vaccination rates protect vulnerable individuals who cannot be vaccinated

wrong.fix: Herd immunity threshold varies by disease (e.g., measles ~95%, polio ~80%)
wrong.action: Threshold depends on disease transmissibility (R0)

wrong.answer: Herd immunity only protects vaccinated individuals
wrong.error: Missing the point of herd immunity
wrong.fix: Herd immunity protects unvaccinated individuals by reducing transmission
wrong.action: Fewer susceptible people = less transmission = protection for all

wrong.answer: Herd immunity is the same as individual immunity
wrong.fix: Herd immunity is a population-level phenomenon that reduces disease circulation
wrong.action: Individual immunity protects one person; herd immunity protects community

persistent.action: Herd immunity: population-level protection, threshold varies, protects vulnerable
